column1: Piracanjuba is a municipality in southeastern Goiás state
column2: Brazil.  It is a big producer of orchids
column4: and soybeans.  Piracanjuba is also the name of a fish (Brycon orbignyanus) common to the waters of the Plata River basin.

column1: Piracanjuba is located southeast of Goiânia.  It is in the valley of the Piracanjuba River
column2: which flows to south to join the Paranaíba.  The important BR-153 highway lies 23 km. to the west.

column1: Distances to important cities are:  Goiânia
column6: 282 km.  The main highways are Go-413
column9: the interstate linking Goiânia with the state of Minas Gerais.  There are municipal boundaries with Morrinhos

column1: The origins of Piracanjuba go back to the nineteenth century when Padre Marinho began a settlement called Pouso Alto.  A chapel was built in 1831 and by 1833 there were houses in the region.  In 1855 it was elevated to district with the name Nossa Senhora da Abadia do Pouso Alto. In 1886 this name was changed to Piracanjuba.  In 1907 once again the name was changed to Pouso Alto
column2: only to return to Piracanjuba in 1943.  Piracanjuba comes from the name of the river and a fish in the region.  Later two districts
column4: were dismembered to form separate municipalities.

column1: The name "Piracanjuba" is derived from the fish with the same name (Triurobrycon lundii)
column2: which was once common in river waters of this region. ambientebrasil

column1: Population growth or loss: a gain of about 150 people since 1980
The economy is based on agriculture
column5: and small transformation industries.  Piracanjuba is considered the state capital of orchids and is one of the largest producers of this flower in Brazil.  Cattle raising
column7: is the most important economic activity
column8: but there are also large plantations of soybeans.

column1: Piracanjuba is famous for its Orchid Exposition
column2: which has been going on for the last 20 years.  It is considered the largest event of this nature in the country
column3: receiving more than 20 thousand visitors and 500 growers.  For photos of the city see Photos of Piracanjuba.
